analyzed: tasmāt liṅgena saṃnidhim apodya ābhicārika karma śeṣa tvam eva āpādyate
translated: Therefore, setting aside proximity by the indicative mark, the state of being a remainder of the magical rite is deduced.

analyzed: yadi api ca upāsanāsu hṛdaya pada mātrasya samaveta artha tvam
translated: And although in the meditations, the word heart alone has a connected meaning,

analyzed: tathā api tad itareṣām sarveṣām eva padānām asamaveta artha tvam
translated: nevertheless, all the other words have a disconnected meaning.

analyzed: ābhicārike tu karmaṇi
translated: But in the magical rite,

analyzed: sarveṣām artha samavāyaḥ iti kim eka pada samaveta artha tā kariṣyati
translated: all have a connected meaning. So what will the connected meaning of a single word do?

analyzed: na ca saṃnidhi upagṛhīyāsu upāsanāsu mantram avasthāpayati iti yuktam
translated: And it is not proper to establish the mantra in the upāsanas as grasped by proximity.

analyzed: hṛdaya padasya abhicāre pi samaveta arthasya itara pada eka vākya tā āpannasya vākya pramāṇa sahitasya ābhicārikāt karmaṇaḥ
translated: For a word like hṛdaya, which has a related meaning even in the case of abhicāra, or which is connected with the other words in the same sentence, or which is supported by the evidence of the sentence, cannot be removed from the abhicārika rite by proximity.

analyzed: saṃnidhinā ācālayitum aśakya tvāt evam deva savitar prasuva yajñam ityādeḥ api yajña prasava liṅgasya
translated: Similarly, even in the case of the mantra beginning with 'O god Savitr, impel the sacrifice', which has the indication of impelling the sacrifice,

original: yajñaṅgatve siddhe jaghanyo vidyāsaṃnidhiḥ kiṃ kariṣyati /
analyzed: yajñaṅga tve siddhe jaghanyaḥ vidyā saṃnidhiḥ kim kariṣyati
translated: when it is established as an auxiliary to the sacrifice, what can the inferior proximity to the vidyā do?

original: evamanyeṣāmapi śvetāśva ityevamādīnāṃ keṣāñcilliṅgena keṣāñcicchutyā keṣāñcitpramāṇāntareṇa prakaraṇeneti /
analyzed: evam anyeṣām api śvetāśvaḥ iti evamādīnām keṣāñcid liṅgena keṣāñcid śutyā keṣāñcid pramāṇa antareṇa prakaraṇena iti
translated: Similarly, in the case of others also, such as 'the white horse' and so on, some are indicated by the liṅga, some by the śruti, and some by the context which is a different means of knowledge.

analyzed: kasmāt punar saṃnidhiḥ liṅga ādibhiḥ bādhyate iti atas āha
translated: And why is proximity contradicted by liṅga and others? To this he says

analyzed: durbalaḥ hi saṃnidhiḥ iti
translated: that proximity is weak.

analyzed: prathama tantra gataḥ ṛthaḥ smāryate
translated: The meaning contained in the first aphorism is recalled.

original: tatra tu śrutiliṅgayoḥ samavāye samānaviṣayatvalakṣaṇe virodhe kiṃ balīya iti cintā /
analyzed: tatra tu śruti liṅgayoḥ samavāye samāna viṣaya tva lakṣaṇe virodhe kim balīyaḥ iti cintā
translated: But there, when there is a conflict between śruti and liṅga, characterized by having the same object, the question is which is stronger.

analyzed: atra udāharaṇam asti aindrī ṛc na indra ityādikā śrutiḥ viniyokī aindryā gārhapatyam upatiṣṭhate iti
translated: Here there is an example. The Aindrī Ṛk beginning with 'Never art thou barren, O Indra' is the Vedic injunction. 'One worships the Gārhapatya with the Aindrī.'

analyzed: atra hi sāmarthya lakṣaṇāt liṅgāt indre viniyogaḥ pratibhāti
translated: Here, from the indication by capability, the application to Indra appears.

original: śruteśca gārhapatyamiti dvitīyāto gārhapatyasya śeṣitvaṃ aindryeti catṛtīyāśruteraindryā ṛcaḥ śeṣatvamavagamyate /
analyzed: śruteḥ ca gārhapatyam iti dvitīyātaḥ gārhapatyasya śeṣi tvam aindryā iti ca tṛtīyā śruteḥ aindryāḥ ṛcaḥ śeṣa tvam avagamyate
translated: And from the second case ending in 'the Gārhapatya' it is understood that the Gārhapatya is the remainder, and from the third case ending in 'by the Aindrī' it is understood that the Aindrī Ṛc is the remainder.

original: yadyapi gārhapatyamiti dvitīyāśruterāgneyīmṛcaṃ prati gārhapatyasya śeṣitvenopapatteḥ /
analyzed: yadi api gārhapatyam iti dvitīyā śruteḥ āgneyīm ṛcam prati gārhapatyasya śeṣi tvena upapatteḥ
translated: Although from the second case ending in 'the Gārhapatya' it is appropriate that the Gārhapatya is the remainder with respect to the Aindrī Ṛc,

original: yadyapi caindryeti ca tṛtīyāśruteraindryā indraṃ prati śeṣatvanopapatteravirodhaḥ /
analyzed: yadi api ca aindryā iti ca tṛtīyā śruteḥ aindryāḥ indram prati śeṣa tvanā upapatteḥ avirodhaḥ
translated: and although there is no contradiction because from the third case ending in 'by the Aindrī' it is appropriate that the Aindrī is the remainder with respect to Indra,

original: padāntarasaṃbandhe tu vākyasyaiva liṅgena virodho na tu śruteḥ /
analyzed: pada antara saṃbandhe tu vākyasya eva liṅgena virodhaḥ na tu śruteḥ
translated: but when there is a connection with another word, the sentence itself is contradicted by the indication, not by the Vedic injunction.

analyzed: tatra ca viparītam balābalam
translated: And there the relative strength is the reverse.

analyzed: tathā api śruti vākyayoḥ rūpataḥ vyāpāra bhedāt adoṣaḥ
translated: Nevertheless, there is no fault because of the difference in function of the Vedic injunction and the sentence, although they are similar in form.

original: dvitīyātṛtīyāśrutī hi kārakavibhaktitayā kriyāṃ prati prakṛtyarthasya karmakaraṇabhāvamavagamayata iti viniyojike /
analyzed: dvitīyā tṛtīyā śrutī hi kāraka vibhakti tayā kriyām prati prakṛti arthasya karma karaṇa bhāvam avagamayataḥ iti viniyojike
translated: For the second and third statements, being case endings indicating agents, make known the state of the primary meaning of the verb as object or instrument with respect to the action, and thus they are injunctive.

original: kriyāṃ prati hi karmaṇaḥ śeṣitvaṃ karaṇasya ca śeṣatvamiti hi viniyogaḥ /🔽padāntarānapekṣe ca kriyāṃ prati śeṣaśeṣitve śrutimātrātpratiyete iti śraute /
analyzed: kriyām prati hi karmaṇaḥ śeṣi tvam karaṇasya ca śeṣa tvam iti hi viniyogaḥ  pada antara anapekṣe ca kriyām prati śeṣa śeṣi tve śruti mātrāt pratiyete iti śraute
translated: For the object has the nature of being subsidiary to the action, and the instrument has the nature of being subordinate, this is the injunction.🔽And when the state of being subsidiary and the state of being subordinate with respect to the action do not depend on another word, they are understood merely from the Vedic statement, thus it is Vedic.

analyzed: saḥ yam śrutitaḥ sāmānya avagataḥ viniyogaḥ pada antara vaśāt viśeṣe vasthāpyate
translated: This injunction, which is generally understood from the Vedic statement, is established in a particular case by the influence of another word.

analyzed: saḥ yam viśeṣaṇa viśeṣya bhāva lakṣaṇaḥ saṃbandhaḥ vākya gocaraḥ
translated: This relation characterized by the relation of qualifier and qualified is based on the sentence.

analyzed: śeṣa śeṣi bhāvaḥ tu śrautaḥ
translated: But the state of being subsidiary and the state of being principal is Vedic.

original: tasmādvākyalabhyaṃ viśeṣamapekṣya śrautaḥ śeṣaśeṣibhāvo liṅgena virudhyata iti śrutiliṅgavirodhe
analyzed: tasmāt vākya labhyam viśeṣam apekṣya śrautaḥ śeṣa śeṣi bhāvaḥ liṅgena virudhyate iti śruti liṅga virodhe
translated: Therefore, the Vedic state of being subsidiary and the state of being principal, which depends on the particularity obtained from the sentence, is contradicted by the indicative. In the contradiction between Vedic statement and indicative,

original: kiṃ liṅgānuguṇena gārhapatyamiti dvitīyāśrutiḥ saptamyarthe vyākhyāyatāṃ gārhapatyasamīpe
analyzed: kim liṅga anuguṇena gārhapatyam iti dvitīyā śrutiḥ saptamī arthe vyākhyāyatām gārhapatya samīpe
translated: either the second statement in the Gārhapatya should be explained as having the sense of the locative in accordance with the indicative, as in the vicinity of the Gārhapatya,

analyzed: aindryā indraḥ upastheyaḥ iti
translated: or Indra should be worshipped in the Aindri (hymn).

analyzed: āho śruti anuguṇa tayā liṅgam vyākhyāyatām
translated: Or the indicative should be explained in accordance with the Vedic statement.

original: prabhavati hi svocitāyāṃ kriyāyāṃ gārhapatya itīndra indrateraiśvaryavacanatvāditi /
analyzed: prabhavati hi sva ucitāyām kriyāyām gārhapatyaḥ iti indraḥ indrateḥ aiśvarya vacana tvāt iti
translated: For the Garhapatya fire is powerful in the action to which it is suited, because Indra is the one who 'indra-s', and 'indra' means 'one who possesses power'.

analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam śruteḥ liṅgam balīyaḥ iti
translated: What is the prima facie view? That the indicative power is stronger than the direct statement.

original: no khalu yatrāsamarthaṃ tacchrutisahasreṇāpi tatra viniyoktuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: no khalu yatra asamartham tat śruti sahasreṇa api tatra viniyoktum śakyate
translated: Indeed, that which is not capable in a certain place cannot be enjoined there even by a thousand direct statements.

analyzed: yathā agninā siñcet pāthasā dahet iti
translated: Like 'one should sprinkle with fire' or 'one should burn with water'.

analyzed: tasmāt sāmarthyam purodhāya śrutyā viniyoktavyam
translated: Therefore, the direct statement should enjoin based on capability.

analyzed: tat ca asyāḥ ṛcaḥ
translated: And that of this Ṛc

analyzed: pramāṇa antarataḥ śabdataḥ ca indre pratīyate
translated: is understood in Indra by other means of knowledge and by the word.

analyzed: tathā hi vidita pada tad arthaḥ kadācana iti ṛcaḥ spaṣṭam indram avagacchati
translated: For thus, one who knows the words and their meanings clearly understands Indra from the Ṛc 'kadā cana'.

analyzed: śabdāt ca aindryā iti atas
translated: And from the word 'aindrī', meaning 'of Indra'.

original: tasmāddārudahanasyeva dahanasya saliladahane viniyogo gārhapatye viniyoga aindryāḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt dāru dahanasya iva dahanasya salila dahane viniyogaḥ gārhapatye viniyogaḥ aindryāḥ
translated: Therefore, just as the burning of wood is enjoined in the burning of water, so is the injunction of the Aindrī verse in the Garhapatya fire.

analyzed: na ca śruti anurodhāt jaghanyām āsthāyāḥ vṛttim sāmarthya kalpanā iti sāmpratam
translated: And it is not right to assume a capability in accordance with the direct statement, taking the less important sense.

analyzed: sāmarthyasya pūrva bhāvi tayā tad anurodhena eva śruti vyavasthāpanāt
translated: Because capability precedes, the direct statement is established in accordance with that alone.

original: tasmādaindryendra eva gārhapatyasamīpa upasthātavya iti prāpte 'bhidhīyate'liṅgajñānaṃ purodhāya na śrutervinayoktṛtā /
analyzed: tasmāt aindryā indraḥ eva gārhapatya samīpe upasthātavyaḥ iti prāpte bhidhīyate liṅga jñānam purodhāya na śruteḥ vinaya uktṛ tā
translated: Therefore, it is concluded that Indra should be worshipped near the Garhapatya fire. In response, it is said: Not relying on the knowledge of the secondary meaning, the injunction is not from the Veda.

analyzed: śruti jñānam purodhāya liṅgam tu viniyojakam
translated: Relying on the knowledge of the primary meaning, the secondary meaning is the determiner.

original: yadi hi sāmarthyamavagamya śruterviniyogamavadhārayetpramātā tataḥ śruterviniyogaṃ prati liṅgajñānāpekṣatvāddurbalatvaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: yadi hi sāmarthyam avagamya śruteḥ viniyogam avadhārayet pramātā tatas śruteḥ viniyogam prati liṅga jñāna apekṣa tvāt durbala tvam bhavet
translated: If the cognizer, having understood the capability, would determine the application from the Veda, then the application of the Veda would be weak with respect to the knowledge of the secondary meaning, because it depends on that.

analyzed: na tu etat asti
translated: But this is not so.

analyzed: śrutiḥ viniyogāya sāmarthyam apekṣate na apekṣate sāmarthya vijñānam
translated: The Veda requires capability for application, but it does not require the knowledge of capability.

original: avagate tu tato viniyoge nāsamarthasya sa iti tannirvāhāya sāmarthyaṃ kalpyate /
analyzed: avagate tu tatas viniyoge na asamarthasya saḥ iti tad nirvāhāya sāmarthyam kalpyate
translated: But when the application is understood, it is imagined that there is capability for its accomplishment, because it is not capable.

analyzed: tad śruti viniyogāt pūrvam asti sāmarthyam
translated: That capability exists before the application by the Veda.

analyzed: na tu pūrvam agamyate
translated: But it is not known before.

original: viniyoge tu siddhe tadanyathānupapattyā paścātpratīyata iti śrutiviniyogātparācīnā sāmarthyapratītistadanurodhenāvasthāpanīyā /
analyzed: viniyoge tu siddhe tad anyathā anupapattyā paścāt pratīyate iti śruti viniyogāt parācīnā sāmarthya pratītiḥ tad anurodhena avasthāpanīyā
translated: But when the application is established, it is subsequently understood by the non-applicability of that, so the understanding of capability is posterior to the application by the Veda and should be established in accordance with that.

original: liṅgaṃ tu na svato viniyojakamapi tu viniyokīṃ kalpayitvā śrutim /
analyzed: liṅgam tu na svatas viniyojakam api tu kalpayitvā śrutim
translated: But the indicative power does not directly apply, but rather it implies a Vedic text that applies.

original: tathāhina svarasato liṅgādanenendra upasthātavya iti pratīyate /
analyzed: tathā hi na svarasataḥ liṅgāt anena indraḥ upasthātavyaḥ iti pratīyate
translated: Thus, from the indicative power alone, it is not understood that Indra is to be worshipped by this.

original: kintvīdṛgindra iti tasya tu prakaraṇāmnānasāmarthyāt sāmānyataḥ prakaraṇāpatitaidamarthyasya
analyzed: kintu īdṛś indraḥ iti tasya tu prakaraṇa āmnāna sāmarthyāt sāmānyatas prakaraṇa āpatita aidamarthyasya
translated: But it is understood that Indra is of this kind. However, due to the capability of the mentioned context, the purpose that falls within the general context

analyzed: tad anyathā anupapattyā viniyoga kalpanāyām api śrautāt viniyogāt kalpanīyasya viniyogasya artha viprakarṣāt śrutiḥ eva
translated: is inferred to be applied by the impossibility of any other way. Even when the application is inferred, the application that is to be inferred is more remote from the meaning than the directly stated application. Therefore, the Vedic text

analyzed: kalpayitum ucitāḥ na tu tad arthaḥ viniyogaḥ
translated: is more suitable to be inferred, but not the application that is its meaning.

analyzed: nahi śrutam anupapannam śākyam arthena upapādayitum
translated: For what is directly stated cannot be explained by the meaning.

original: nahi trayo 'tra brahmaṇāḥ kaṭhakauṇḍinyāviti vākyaṃ pramāṇāntaropasthāpitena māṭhareṇopapādayanti /
analyzed: nahi kaṭha kauṇḍinyau iti vākyam pramāṇa antara upasthāpitena māṭhareṇa upapādayanti
translated: For the sentence Here there are three Brahmins, Katha and Kaundinya is not explained by the Māṭhara who is presented by another means of knowledge.

analyzed: upapādayataḥ vā na upahasanti
translated: Or if it is explained, it is not ridiculed.

analyzed: śābdāḥ
translated: The verbal ones.

analyzed: māṭharaḥ ca iti tu śrāvayantam anumanyante
translated: But they agree with one who recites and the Māṭhara.

analyzed: tasmāt śruta artha samutthāna anupapattiḥ śrutena eva artha antareṇa upapādanīyā
translated: Therefore, the impossibility of arising from the directly stated meaning should be explained by another directly stated meaning.

analyzed: na artha antara mātreṇa pramāṇa antara upanītena iti loka siddham
translated: It is well known that (the meaning of a word) is not (determined) by (the mere fact of) its being mentioned by another means of knowledge, which is something entirely different (from the word itself).

analyzed: na ca loka siddhasya niyoga anuyogau yujyete śabda artha jñāna upāya bhūta loka virodhāt
translated: And it is not proper to raise questions or objections (as to the meaning of a word) which is well known, because such (questions and objections) are opposed to the common experience of men, which is the means of knowing the meaning of words.

original: tasmādviniyojikā śrutiḥ kalpanīyā /🔽tathāca yāvalliṅgādviniyojikāṃ śrutiṃ kalpayituṃ prakrāntavyāpārastāvatpratyakṣayā🔽śrutyā gārhapatye viniyogaḥ siddha iti nivṛttākāṅkṣaṃ prakaraṇamiti kasyānupapattyā
analyzed: tasmāt viniyojikā śrutiḥ kalpanīyā  tathā ca yāvat liṅgāt viniyojikām śrutim kalpayitum prakrānta vyāpāraḥ tāvat pratyakṣayā  śrutyā gārhapatye viniyogaḥ siddhaḥ iti nivṛtta ākāṅkṣam prakaraṇam iti kasya anupapattyā
translated: Therefore, an injunctive Vedic text must be assumed (to determine the meaning of the word 'agni').🔽And so long as (the commentator) has not begun to assume an injunctive Vedic text (to determine the meaning of the word 'agni') by the process of reasoning based on the indicative power (of the word 'agni'), the direct Vedic text (which enjoins the offering of the cake to Agni) has already established the application of the word 'agni' to the Garhapatya fire.

analyzed: liṅgam viniyokīm śrutim upakalpayet
translated: Thus the context, having had its requirements satisfied, ceases to be operative. Then, what inconsistency (in the meaning of the word 'agni') would there be, on account of which (the commentator) would assume an injunctive Vedic text (to determine the meaning of the word 'agni') on the basis of the indicative power (of the word 'agni')?

analyzed: mantra samāmnānasya pratyakṣayā eva viniyoga śrutyā upapādita tvāt
translated: Because the direct Vedic text itself explains the application of the recitation of the mantra.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ yāvat ajñāta saṃdigdham jñeyam tāvat pramitsyate
translated: As they say: 'As long as the knowable is unknown or doubtful, so long is there a desire to know it.

analyzed: pramite tu pramātṛṇām pramā autsukyam vihanyate iti
translated: But when it is known, the eagerness of the knowers to know it is frustrated.'

original: tasmātpratītaśrautaviniyogopapattyai mantrasya sāmarthyaṃ tadanuguṇatvena nīyamānaṃ prathamāṃ vṛttimajahajjaghanyayāpi neyamiti siddham /
analyzed: tasmāt pratīta śrauta viniyoga upapattyai mantrasya sāmarthyam tad anuguṇa tvena nīyamānam prathamām vṛttim ajahat jaghanyayā api neyam iti siddham
translated: Therefore, in order to explain the application of the mantra, which is known from the Vedic text, the meaning of the mantra is to be taken as having a secondary meaning, which is in accordance with the primary meaning, without abandoning the primary meaning, even though it is of a lower order. This is the conclusion.

original: liṅgavākyayoriha virodho yathā'syonaṃ te sadanaṃ kṛṇomi ghṛtasya dhārayā suśevaṃ kalpayāmi /
analyzed: liṅga vākyayoḥ iha virodhaḥ yathā asya ūnam te sadanam kṛṇomi ghṛtasya dhārayā su śevam kalpayāmi
translated: As for the conflict between Indicative Power and Syntactical Connection, it is illustrated in the following: 'I make for thee a comfortable seat, I prepare it with the stream of ghee.

analyzed: tasmin sīda amṛte pratitiṣṭha vrīhīṇām medha sumanasyamānaḥ iti
translated: Sit on that, O immortal one, stand firm, O sacrificial cake, well-disposed.'

original: kimayaṃ kṛtsna eva mantraḥ sadanakaraṇe puroḍāśāsādane ca prayoktavya uta kalpayāmyanta upastaraṇe tasmintsīdetyevamādistu puroḍāśāsādana iti
analyzed: kim ayam kṛtsnaḥ eva mantraḥ sadana karaṇe puroḍāśa āsādane ca prayoktavyaḥ uta kalpayāmi ante upastaraṇe tasmin sīda iti evamādiḥ tu puroḍāśa āsādane iti
translated: Should this entire mantra be used both in making the seat and in placing the cake, or is the part ending with 'I prepare' to be used in spreading, and the part beginning with 'Sit on that' etc. only in placing the cake?

original: yadi vākyaṃ balīyaḥ kṛtsno mantra ubhayatra /
analyzed: yadi vākyam balīyaḥ kṛtsnaḥ mantraḥ ubhayatra
translated: If syntactical connection is stronger, then the entire mantra is to be used in both cases.

original: suśevaṃ kalpayāmītyetadapekṣo hi tasminsīdetyādiḥ pūrveṇaikavākyatāmupaiti yatkalpayāmi tasmintsīdeti /🔽atha liṅgaṃ balīyastataḥ kalpyāmyantaḥ sadanakaraṇe tatprakāśane hi tatsamartham /
analyzed: su śevam kalpayāmi iti etad apekṣaḥ hi tasmin sīda ityādiḥ pūrveṇa ekavākyatām upaiti yat kalpayāmi tasmin sīda iti  atha liṅgam balīyaḥ tatas kalpyāmi antar sadana karaṇe tad prakāśane hi tat samartham
translated: For the part beginning with 'Sit on that' etc. is connected in one sentence with the preceding part, which is dependent on 'I prepare', as 'I prepare, on that sit'.🔽If indicative power is stronger, then the part ending with 'I prepare' is to be used in making the seat, for that is capable of illuminating it.

analyzed: tasmin sīda iti puroḍāśa āsādane tatra hi tat samartham iti
translated: And the part beginning with 'Sit on that' is to be used in placing the cake, for that is capable of that.

analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam
translated: What is the prima facie view?

original: liṅgādvākyaṃ balīya ityubhayatra kṛtsnasya viniyoga iti /
analyzed: liṅgāt vākyam balīyaḥ iti ubhayatra kṛtsnasya viniyogaḥ iti
translated: Indicative power is stronger than syntactical connection, so the entire mantra is to be used in both cases.

original: iha hi yattatpadasamabhivyāhāreṇa vibhajyamānasākāṅkṣatvādekavākyatāyāṃ siddhāyāṃ tadanurodhena paścāttadabhidhānasāmārthyaṃ kalpanīyam /🔽yathā devasyatvetimantre 'gnye nirvapāmīti padayoḥ samavetārthatvena tadekavākyatayā padāntarāṇāṃ tatparatvena tatra sāmarthyakalpanā /
analyzed: iha hi yat tad pada samabhivyāhāreṇa vibhajyamāna sākāṅkṣa tvāt ekavākya tāyām siddhāyām tad anurodhena paścāt tad abhidhāna sāmārthyam kalpanīyam  yathā devasya tvā iti mantre gnye nirvapāmi iti padayoḥ samaveta artha tvena tad ekavākya tayā pada antarāṇām tad paratvena tatra sāmarthya kalpanā
translated: For here, when the unity of the sentence is established by the fact that the sentence is complete with all its requirements when divided by the occurrence of the word tat, then the capability of expressing that [tat] is to be assumed in accordance with that [unity of the sentence].🔽Just as in the mantra devasyatv etc., the words agnau nirvapāmi have a related meaning, and by their unity with that [mantra], the other words are assumed to have the capability of referring to that [agni].

original: tadevaṃ pratītaikavākyatānirvāhāya tadanuguṇatayā sāmarthyaṃ kḷptaṃ sanna tadvyāpādayitumarhati / api tu
analyzed: tat evam pratīta ekavākya tā nirvāhāya tad anuguṇa tayā sāmarthyam kḷptam sat na tat vyāpādayitum arhati api tu
translated: Thus, in order to establish the unity of the sentence that is thus understood, the capability is assumed in accordance with that [unity of the sentence]. Having been established in this way, it cannot be contradicted. But

analyzed: viniyojikām śrutim kalpayat tad anuguṇam eva kalpayet
translated: when assuming an injunctive Vedic text, it should be assumed in accordance with that [unity of the sentence].

original: tathā ca vākyasya liṅgato balīyastvātsadanakaraṇe ca puroḍāśāsādhane ca kṛtsna eva mantraḥ prayoktavya iti prāptam /
analyzed: tathā ca vākyasya liṅgataḥ balīyaḥ tvāt sadana karaṇe ca puroḍāśa asādhane ca kṛtsnaḥ eva mantraḥ prayoktavyaḥ iti prāptam
translated: And thus, since a sentence is stronger than an indication, the entire mantra should be used both in making the seat and in preparing the cake. This is the conclusion.

analyzed: evam prāpte ucyate bhavet etat evam yadi eka vākyatā avagama pūrvam sāmarthya avadhāraṇam api
translated: When this has been reached, it is said: This would be so if the determination of capability were preceded by the understanding of unity of the sentence.

original: tu avadhṛtasāmarthyānāṃ padānāṃ praśliṣṭapaṭhitānāṃ sāmarthyavaśena prayojanaikatvenekavākyatvāvadhāraṇam /
analyzed: tu avadhṛta sāmarthyānām padānām praśliṣṭa paṭhitānām sāmarthya vaśena prayojana ekatvena ika vākya tva avadhāraṇam
translated: When the meanings of words whose capability is ascertained are read in close proximity, their unity into a single sentence is determined by the unity of purpose based on their capability.

original: yāvanti padāni pradhānamekamarthamavagamayituṃ samarthāni vibhāge sākāṅkṣāṇi tānyekaṃ vākyam /
analyzed: yāvanti padāni pradhānam ekam artham avagamayitum samarthāni vibhāge sākāṅkṣāṇi tāni ekam vākyam
translated: As many words as are capable of conveying a single principal meaning, which are wanting in parts, they form a single sentence.

analyzed: anuṣṭheyaḥ ca arthaḥ mantreṣu prakāśyamānaḥ pradhānam
translated: And the meaning to be performed, which is revealed in the mantras, is the principal one.

analyzed: sadana karaṇa puroḍāśa āsādane ca anuṣṭheya tayā pradhāne
translated: And the making of the seat and the placing of the cake are principal as what is to be performed.

original: tayośca sadanakaraṇaṃ kalpayāmyanto mantraḥ samarthaḥ prakāśayituṃ puroḍāśāsādanaṃ ca tasminsīdetyādiḥ /🔽tataśca yāvadekavākyatāvaśena sāmarthyamanumīyate tāvatpratītaṃ sāmarthyamekaikasya bhāgasyaikaikasminnarthe viniyojikāṃ śrutiṃ kalpayati /
analyzed: tayoḥ ca sadana karaṇam kalpayāmi antaḥ mantraḥ samarthaḥ prakāśayitum puroḍāśa āsādanam ca tasmin sīda ityādiḥ  tatas ca yāvat eka vākya tā vaśena sāmarthyam anumīyate tāvat pratītam sāmarthyam ekaikasya bhāgasya ekaikasmin arthe viniyojikām śrutim kalpayati
translated: And the mantra ending with I imagine the making of the seat is capable of revealing the placing of the cake, and the one beginning with Sit in that is capable of revealing the making of the seat.🔽And thus, as long as the capability is inferred based on the unity of the sentence, the capability that is understood generates an injunctive Vedic text for each part in each meaning.

original: tathāca śrutyaivaikaikasya bhāgasyaikatra viniyoge sati prakaraṇapāṭhopapattau na
analyzed: tathā ca śrutyā eva ekaikasya bhāgasya ekatra viniyoge sati prakaraṇa pāṭha upapattau na
translated: And thus, when each part is enjoined in one place by the Vedic text itself, the recitation in the context is appropriate.

original: vākyakalpitaṃ liṅgaṃ viniyojikāṃ śrutimaparāṃ kalpayitumarhatītyekavākyatābuddhirutpannāpyābhāsībhavati liṅgena bādhanāt /
analyzed: vākya kalpitam liṅgam viniyojikām śrutim aparām kalpayitum arhati iti ekavākya tā buddhiḥ utpannā api ābhāsībhavati liṅgena bādhanāt
translated: The indication supplied by the sentence can at best only assume a distinct Vedic text enjoining the use of the mantra, and as such, being weaker in authority, it is set aside by the more authoritative indication supplied by the mantra itself.

original: yatra tu virodhakaṃ liṅgaṃ nāsti tatra samavetārthaikadvitripadaikavākyatā padāntarāṇāmapi sāmarthyaṃ kalpayatīti bhavati vākyasya viniyojakatvam
analyzed: yatra tu virodhakam liṅgam nā asti tatra samaveta artha eka dvi tri pada eka vākyatā pada antarāṇām api sāmarthyam kalpayati iti bhavati vākyasya viniyojaka tvam
translated: In a case, however, where there is no such contradictory indication, the sentence is quite competent to assume the necessary syntactical connection of the other words also, and thus to supply the required meaning, and as such, it becomes the means of enjoining the use of the mantra.

analyzed: yathā atra eva syonam te ityādīnām
translated: For instance, in the case of the mantra, Syonam te, etc.

analyzed: tasmāt vākyāt liṅgam balīyaḥ iti siddham
translated: From all this it follows that the indication supplied by the mantra is more authoritative than that supplied by the sentence.

analyzed: vākya prakaraṇayoḥ virodha udāharaṇam
translated: An example of the conflict between sentence and context.

original: atra ca padānāṃ parasparāpekṣāvaśātkasmiṃścidviśiṣṭa ekasminnarthe paryavasitānāṃ vākyatvaṃ /
analyzed: atra ca padānām paraspara apekṣā vaśāt kasmiṃścid viśiṣṭe ekasmin arthe paryavasitānām vākya tvam
translated: Here, the words, by virtue of their mutual dependence, converge upon a single qualified meaning, and thus constitute a sentence.

original: labdhavākyabhāvanāṃ ca punaḥ kāryāntarāpekṣāvaśena vākyāntareṇa saṃbandhaḥ prakaraṇam /🔽kartavyāyāḥ khalu phalabhāvanāyā labdhadhātvarthakaraṇāyā itikartavyatākāṅkṣāyā vacanaṃ
analyzed: labdha vākya bhāvanām ca punar kārya antara apekṣā vaśena vākya antareṇa saṃbandhaḥ prakaraṇam  kartavyāyāḥ khalu phala bhāvanāyāḥ labdha dhātvartha karaṇāyāḥ itikartavya tā ākāṅkṣāyāḥ vacanam
translated: And when the sentence has been duly formed, it is again connected with another sentence, by virtue of its dependence upon another action, and this is called Context.

analyzed: prakaraṇam ācakṣate vṛddhāḥ
translated: The elders call that Context which is the statement of the necessary details for the fruit-producing action, which has obtained the means of accomplishment through the verbal root, and which is in need of the necessary details.

analyzed: yathā darśa pūrṇamāsābhyām svarga kāmaḥ yajeta eti
translated: As in the case of the injunction, 'One who desires heaven should sacrifice with the new and full moon sacrifices.'

analyzed: etat hi vacanam prakaraṇam
translated: For this statement is the context.

original: tadetasmin svapadagaṇena kiyatyapyarthe paryavasite karaṇopakāralakṣaṇakāryāntarāpekṣāyāṃ 'samidho yajati'ityādivākyāntarasaṃbandhaḥ /
analyzed: tat etasmin sva pada gaṇena kiyati api arthe paryavasite karaṇa upakāra lakṣaṇa kārya antara apekṣāyām samidhaḥ yajati ityādi vākya antara saṃbandhaḥ
translated: And when this [context] has come to an end even with a small amount of meaning expressed by its own group of words, and there is a need for another effect in the form of assistance to the instrument, there is a connection with another sentence such as 'One offers the kindling wood.'

original: samidādibhāvanā hi svavidhyupahitāḥ puruṣe hitaṃ bhāvyamapekṣamāṇā viśvajitryāyena vānuṣaṅgato vārthavādato vā phalāntarāpratilambhena darśapūrṇamāsabhāvanāṃ 🔽nirvārayitumīśate /
analyzed: samidh ādi bhāvanāḥ hi sva vidhi upahitāḥ puruṣe hitam bhāvyam apekṣamāṇāḥ viśvaji tryāyena vā anuṣaṅgataḥ vā arthavādataḥ vā phala antara apratilambhena darśa pūrṇamāsa bhāvanām  nirvārayitum īśate
translated: For the performances related to the kindling wood and so on, when they are engaged by their own injunctions and require something to be accomplished for the sake of the person, are able to set aside the performance of the new and full moon sacrifices without obtaining another result by implication, by the Viśvajit, or by arthavāda.

original: tasmāttadākāṅkṣāyāmupanipatitānyetāni vākyāni svakāryāpekṣāṇi tadapekṣitakaraṇopakāralakṣaṇaṃ kāryamāsādya nirvaṇvanti ca nirvārayanti ca pradhānam
analyzed: tasmāt tad ākāṅkṣāyām upanipatitāni etāni vākyāni sva kārya apekṣāṇi tad apekṣita karaṇa upakāra lakṣaṇam kāryam āsādya nirvaṇvanti ca nirvārayanti ca pradhānam
translated: Therefore, when there is a need for that, these sentences, which are related to their own purpose, accomplish their function, which is characterized by assistance to the instrument that is required by them, and they both accomplish and set aside the primary [sacrifice].

analyzed: saḥ yam anayoḥ naṣṭa aśva dagdha ratha vat saṃyogaḥ
translated: This connection between them is like a lost horse and a burnt chariot.

analyzed: tat evam lakṣaṇayoḥ vākya prakaraṇayoḥ virodha udāharaṇam sūktavāka nigadaḥ
translated: Thus, the Sūktavāka and Nigada are an example of the contradiction between the two indications of sentence and context.

original: tatra hi paurṇamāsīdevatā amāvasyādevatāḥ samāmnātāḥ /🔽tāśca na mitha ekavākyatāṃ gantumarhantīti liṅgena paurṇamāsīyāgādindrāgnīśabda utkraṣṭavyaḥ amāvāsyāyāṃ ca samavetārthatvātprayoktavyaḥ /
analyzed: tatra hi paurṇamāsī devatāḥ amāvasyā devatāḥ samāmnātāḥ  tāḥ ca na mithas ekavākya tām gantum arhanti iti liṅgena paurṇamāsī yāgāt indra agnī śabdaḥ utkraṣṭavyaḥ amāvāsyāyām ca samaveta artha tvāt prayoktavyaḥ
translated: For there, the deities of the full moon are mentioned as the deities of the new moon.🔽And they cannot be syntactically connected with each other. Therefore, by the indication, the word 'Indra-Agni' belonging to the full moon sacrifice should be extracted, and it should be used in the new moon sacrifice because it has a related meaning.

original: athedānīṃ saṃdihyatekiṃ yadindrāgnipadaikavākyatayā pratīyate 'avivṛdhethāṃ maho jyāyo 'kātām'iti tannotkraṣṭavyamutendrāgniśabdābhyāṃ sahotkraṣṭavyamiti
analyzed: atha idānīm saṃdihyate kim yat indra agni pada eka vākya tayā pratīyate avivṛdhethām mahaḥ jyāyaḥ kātām iti tat na utkraṣṭavyam uta indra agni śabdābhyām saha utkraṣṭavyam iti
translated: Now, this is doubted: If it is understood to be syntactically connected with the word 'Indra-Agni' as 'You two should not increase, you have made the greater', then should it not be extracted, or should it be extracted along with the words 'Indra' and 'Agni'?

original: tatra yadi prakaraṇaṃ balīyastato 'panītadevatāko 'pi śeṣaḥ prayoktavyo 'tha vākyaṃ tato yatra devatāśabdastatraiva prayoktavyaḥ /
analyzed: tatra yadi prakaraṇam balīyaḥ tatas upanīta devatākaḥ śeṣaḥ prayoktavyaḥ vākyam tatas yatra devatā śabdaḥ tatra eva prayoktavyaḥ
translated: There, if the context is stronger, then even the remainder with its deity removed should be used. If it is the sentence, then it should be used only where there is a word for the deity.

analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam apanīta devatākaḥ śeṣaḥ prayoktavyaḥ prakaraṇasya eva aṅga saṃbandha pratipādaka tvāt
translated: What is the prima facie view? Even the remainder with its deity removed should be used, because the context alone indicates the connection with the subsidiary.

analyzed: phalavatī hi bhāvanā pradhāna itikartavya tā tvam āpādayati
translated: For the fruitful action imposes the nature of being the primary and subsidiary upon the other.

analyzed: tad upajīvanena śruti ādīnām viśeṣa saṃbandha āpādaka tvāt
translated: Because the specific connection is imposed by the direct statement etc. which depend on that.

analyzed: atas pradhāna bhāvanā vacana lakṣaṇa prakaraṇa virodhe tad upajīvi vākyam bādhyate iti prāptam
translated: Therefore, when there is a conflict between the context characterized by the statement of the principal injunction and the subordinate sentence, the latter is overridden.

original: evaṃ prāpta ucyatebhavedetadevaṃ yadi viniyojyasvarūpasāmarthyamanapekṣya prakaraṇaṃ viniyojayet /
analyzed: evam prāptaḥ ucyate bhavet etat evam yadi viniyojya sva rūpa sāmarthyam an apekṣya prakaraṇam viniyojayet
translated: This would be so if the context were to apply without regard to the capability of the object to be applied.

original: api tu viniyogāya tadapekṣate 'nyathā pūṣādyanumantraṇamantrasya dvādaśopasattāyāśca notkarṣaḥ syāt /
analyzed: api tu viniyogāya tat apekṣate nyathā pūṣa ādi anumantraṇa mantrasya dvādaśa upasattāyāḥ ca na utkarṣaḥ syāt
translated: But it requires that, otherwise there would be no elevation of the mantra for the subsequent recitation of Pūṣan and the twelfth pressing.

analyzed: tad rūpa ālocanāyām ca yat yat eva śīghram pratīyate
translated: And in the consideration of that form, whatever is quickly understood

analyzed: tat tat balavat viprakṛṣṭam tu durbalam
translated: that is strong, but what is distant is weak.

original: tatra yadi tadrūpaṃ śrutyā liṅgena vākyena vānyatra viniyuktaṃ tataḥ
analyzed: tatra yadi tad rūpam śrutyā liṅgena vākyena vā anyatra viniyuktam tatas
translated: And if that form is applied elsewhere by Śruti, by Linga, or by Vākya, then

analyzed: prakaraṇam bhaṅktvā utkṛṣyate
translated: it is elevated by breaking the context.

analyzed: pariśiṣṭaiḥ tu prakaraṇasya itikartavya tā apekṣā pūryate
translated: But the remaining ones fulfill the expectation of the subsidiary nature of the context.

original: atha svasya śīghrapravṛttaṃ śrutyādi nāsti tataḥ prakaraṇaṃ viniyojakam /
analyzed: atha svasya śīghra pravṛttam śruti ādi nā asti tatas prakaraṇam viniyojakam
translated: But if there is no Śruti etc. that quickly operates for itself, then the context is the applying factor.

analyzed: yathā samidh ādeḥ
translated: Like in the case of the kindling wood etc.

analyzed: tat iha prakaraṇāt vākyasya śīghra pravṛtta tvam ucyate
translated: Here, the quick operation of the sentence by the context is stated.

analyzed: prakaraṇe hi svārtha pūrṇānām vākyānām upakārya upakāraka ākāṅkṣā mātram dṛśyate
translated: For in a context, only the mere expectancy of the sentences, which are complete in their own meaning, as being helpful or helped, is seen.

analyzed: vākye tu padānām pratyakṣa saṃbandhaḥ
translated: But in a sentence, there is an actual connection between the words.

analyzed: tatas ca saha prasthitayoḥ vākya prakaraṇayoḥ yāvat prakaraṇena eka vākya tā kalpyate tāvat vākyena abhidhāna sāmarthyam
translated: Therefore, when the sentence and the context have started together, as long as the oneness of the sentence is assumed by the context, for that long the sentence has the capacity to denote.

original: yāvaditaratra vākyena sāmarthyaṃ tāvaditaratra sāmarthyena śrutiryāvaditaratra sāmarthyena
analyzed: yāvat itaratra vākyena sāmarthyam tāvat itaratra sāmarthyena śrutiḥ yāvat itaratra sāmarthyena
translated: As long as the sentence has the capacity in one place, for that long the hearing has the capacity by the hearing in another place.

original: śrutistāvadiha śrutyā viniyogastāvatā ca vicchinnāyāmākāṅkṣāyāṃ śrutyanumāne vihate
analyzed: śrutiḥ tāvat iha śrutyāḥ viniyogaḥ tāvatā ca vicchinnāyām ākāṅkṣāyām śruti anumāne vihate
translated: As long as the hearing has the capacity in another place, for that long the application is by the hearing here. By that much, when the expectancy is interrupted, the inference of the hearing being defeated,

original: prakaraṇenāntarā kalpitaṃ vilīyanta iti vākyabalīyastvāttaddevatāśeṣaṇāmapakarṣa eveti siddham //
analyzed: prakaraṇena antarā kalpitam vilīyante iti vākya balīyaḥ tvāt tad devatā śeṣaṇām apakarṣaḥ eva iti siddham
translated: it dissolves by the context. Thus, by the strength of the sentence, it is established that the subsidiary nature of the deity is only removed.

analyzed: krama prakaraṇa virodha udāharaṇam
translated: An example of the contradiction between sequence and context.

analyzed: rājasūya prakaraṇe pradhānasya eva abhiṣecanīyasya saṃnidhau śaunaḥśepa upākhyāna ādi āmnātam
translated: In the context of the Rajasuya, the story of Shunahshepa and others is narrated in the presence of the main Abhisechaniya rite.

analyzed: tat kim samastasya rājasūyasya aṅgam uta abhiṣecanīyasya
translated: Is that an auxiliary to the entire Rajasuya or to the Abhisechaniya?

analyzed: yadi prakaraṇam balīyaḥ tatas samastasya rājasūyasya
translated: If context is stronger, then of the entire Rajasuya.

analyzed: atha kramaḥ tatas bhiṣecanīyasya eva iti
translated: If sequence, then of the Abhisecaniya alone.

analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam
translated: What is the prima facie view?

analyzed: na ākāṅkṣā mātram hi saṃbandha hetuḥ
translated: For mere expectancy is not the cause of connection.

original: gāmānaya prāsādaṃ paśyeti gāmityasya kriyāmātrāpekṣiṇaḥ paśyetyanenāpi saṃbandhasaṃbhavādvinigamanābhāvaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: gām ānaya prāsādam paśya iti gām iti asya kriyā mātra apekṣiṇaḥ paśya iti anena api saṃbandha saṃbhavāt vinigamana abhāva prasaṅgāt
translated: For the word cow which requires only a verb, could be connected with see as in bring the cow, see the palace, leading to the fallacy of indeterminacy.

analyzed: tasmāt saṃnidhānam saṃbandha kāraṇam
translated: Therefore, proximity is the cause of connection.

analyzed: tathā ca anayā iti ananā eva gām iti asya saṃbandhaḥ vinigamyate
translated: And thus the connection of cow is determined by bring alone.

analyzed: na ca saṃnidhānam api saṃbandha kāraṇam
translated: And proximity is not the cause of connection.

original: ayameti putro rājñaḥ puruṣo 'pasāryatāmityatra rājña ityasya putrapuruṣapadasaṃnidhānāviśeṣānmā bhūdavinigamanā /
analyzed: ayam eti putraḥ rājñaḥ puruṣaḥ upasāryatām iti atra rājñaḥ iti asya putra puruṣa pada saṃnidhāna aviśeṣāt mā bhūt avinigamanā
translated: In this son of the king is coming, remove the man, due to the non-distinction of the proximity of the word of the king with son and man, there should not be indeterminacy.

analyzed: tasmāt ākāṅkṣā niścaya hetuḥ vaktavyā
translated: Therefore, expectancy must be stated as the cause of determination.

original: atra putraśabdasya saṃbandhivacanatayā samutthitākāṅkṣasyāntike yadupanipatitaṃ saṃbandhyantarākāṅkṣaṃ padaṃ tasya tenaivākāṅkṣāparipūrteḥ
analyzed: atra putra śabdasya saṃbandhi vacana tayā samutthita ākāṅkṣasya antike yat upanipatitam saṃbandhi antara ākāṅkṣam padam tasya tena eva ākāṅkṣā paripūrteḥ
translated: Here, the word son having arisen with expectancy as a word expressing a related term, that word which has fallen near it with expectancy for another related term,

analyzed: puruṣa rūpa mātra abhidhāyinā svatantreṇa eva na saṃbandhaḥ kintu pareṇa apasāryatām iti anena apasaraṇīya apekṣeṇa iti
translated: The connection is not with the independent word 'man' alone, but with the word 'man' as related to the word 'remove' which expresses the necessity of removal.

analyzed: sati api saṃnidhāne ākāṅkṣā bhāvāt asaṃbandhaḥ
translated: Even when present, there is no connection due to the absence of expectancy.

analyzed: tathā ca ābhāṇakaḥ taptam taptena saṃbadhyate iti
translated: And thus the Ābhāṇakas say: 'The heated is connected with the heated.'

original: tathā cākāṅkṣitamapi na yāvatsaṃnidhāpyate tāvanna saṃbadhyate /
analyzed: tathā ca ākāṅkṣitam api na yāvat saṃnidhāpyate tāvat na saṃbadhyate
translated: And thus, even if expected, it is not connected until it is brought near.

original: tathā saṃnihitamapi yāvannākāṅkṣyate na tāvatsaṃbadhyata iti dvayoḥ saṃbandhaṃ prati
analyzed: tathā saṃnihitam api yāvat na ākāṅkṣyate na tāvat saṃbadhyate iti dvayoḥ saṃbandham prati
translated: And thus, even if brought near, it is not connected until it is expected. Thus, in regard to the connection of the two,

analyzed: samāna bala tvāt krama prakaraṇayoḥ samuccaya asaṃbhavāt ca vikalpena rājasūya abhiṣecanīyayoḥ viniyogaḥ
translated: because of the equal strength of sequence and context, and because of the impossibility of combination, the application is by option between the Rājasūya and the Abhiṣeचaniya.

analyzed: śaunaḥśepa upākhyāna ādīnām iti prāptam
translated: The conclusion is that the stories of Śunaḥśepa and others are to be applied.

original: evaṃ prāpta ucyaterājasūyake kathaṃbhāvāpekṣā hi pavitrādārabhya kṣatrasya dhṛtiṃ yāvadanuvartate /
analyzed: evam prāptaḥ ucyate rājasūyake kathaṃbhāva apekṣā hi pavitrāt ārabhya kṣatrasya dhṛtim yāvat anuvartate
translated: This being the prima facie view, it is said: The Rājasūya requires the manner of performance beginning from the purification up to the support of the warrior class.

analyzed: yathā ca avicchinne kathaṃbhāve yat pradhānasya paṭhyate
translated: And just as what is recited in regard to the principal rite when the manner of performance is not interrupted,

original: anirjñātaphalaṃ karma tasya prakaraṇāṅgatā 'iti nyāyādrājasūyāṅgatā śaunaḥśepopākhyānādīnām /
analyzed: a nirjñāta phalam karma tasya prakaraṇa aṅga tā iti nyāyāt rājasūya aṅga tā śaunaḥśepa upākhyāna ādīnām
translated: The story of Shunahshepa and so on are subsidiary to the Rajasuya by the principle that an action whose result is unknown is subsidiary to the context in which it occurs.

original: abhiṣecanīyasya tu svavākyopāttapadārthanirākāṅkṣasya saṃnidhipāṭhenākāṅkṣotthāpanīyā yāvattāvatsiddhākāṅkṣeṇa rājasūyenaikavākyatā kalpyate🔽yāvaccābhiṣecanīyākāṅkṣyā tadekavākyatā kalpyate tāvatkḷptayā rājasūyaikavākyatā
analyzed: abhiṣecanīyasya tu sva vākya upātta padārtha nirākāṅkṣasya saṃnidhi pāṭhena ākāṅkṣā utthāpanīyā yāvat tāvat siddha ākāṅkṣeṇa rājasūyena ekavākya tā kalpyate  yāvat ca abhiṣecanīya ākāṅkṣyā tad eka vākya tā kalpyate tāvat kḷptayā rājasūya eka vākya tā
translated: But for the Abhisecaniya, which has its requirements fulfilled by the words contained in its own text, the requirement is to be produced by the proximity of the recitation, and it is assumed to be syntactically connected with the Rajasuya, which has its requirements fulfilled, to the extent that is necessary.🔽And to the extent that the Abhisecaniya is assumed to be syntactically connected, that extent of the Rajasuya's syntactic connection is established.

original: tadupakāratayā sāmarthyalakṣaṇaṃ liṅgaṃ yāvaccābhiṣecanīyaikavākyatayā liṅgaṃ kalpyate🔽tāvatkḷptaliṅgaṃ viniyokrīṃ śrutiṃ kalpyati yāvadvākyakalpitena liṅgena śrutiritaratra
analyzed: tad upakāra tayā sāmarthya lakṣaṇam liṅgam yāvat ca abhiṣecanīya eka vākya tayā liṅgam kalpyate  tāvat kḷpta liṅgam viniyokrīm śrutim kalpyati yāvat vākya kalpitena liṅgena śrutiḥ itaratra
translated: And to the extent that the Abhisecaniya's syntactic connection is assumed by the indicative mark of capability, which is the helper of that, to that extent the assumed syntactic connection of the Rajasuya🔽is assumed by the indicative mark assumed by the syntactic connection with the Abhisecaniya.🔽And to the extent that the assumed indicative mark assumes the injunction by the Vedic text, to that extent the assumed Vedic text🔽assumes the injunction elsewhere by the indicative mark assumed by the sentence.

original: kalpyate tāvatkḷptayā śrutyā viniyoge sati prakaraṇapāṭhopapattau saṃnidhānaparikalpitamantarā vilīyate /
analyzed: kalpyate tāvat kḷptayā śrutyā viniyoge sati prakaraṇa pāṭha upapattau saṃnidhāna parikalpitam antarā vilīyate
translated: When the injunction is assumed by the assumed Vedic text, the proximity assumed by the recitation of the context dissolves in the middle, without being assumed.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāve pratipa tvāt
translated: Because of the absence of a means of knowledge, there is no cognition.

analyzed: prakaraṇinaḥ ca rājasūyasya sarvadā buddhi sāṃnidhyena tad saṃnidheḥ a kalpanīya tvāt
translated: And the context of the Rajasuya sacrifice is always present in the mind, so its proximity cannot be imagined.

original: tasmātprakaraṇavirodhe kramasya bādha eva naca vikalpo durbalatvāditi siddham //
analyzed: tasmāt prakaraṇa virodhe kramasya bādhaḥ eva na ca vikalpaḥ durbala tvāt iti siddham
translated: Therefore, when there is a conflict with the context, the order is indeed overridden, and there is no option due to its weakness. Thus it is established.

original: kramasamākhyayorvirodhodāharaṇampauroḍāśika iti samākhyāte kāṇḍe sānnāyyakrame ca śundhadhvaṃ daivyāya karmaṇa iti śundhanārtho mantraḥ samāmnātaḥ /
analyzed: krama samākhyayoḥ virodha udāharaṇam pauroḍāśikaḥ iti samākhyāte kāṇḍe sānnāyya krame ca śundhadhvam daivyāya karmaṇe iti śundhana arthaḥ mantraḥ samāmnātaḥ
translated: An example of the conflict between order and designation: In the section designated as related to the purodasha cakes, in the order of the sannayya ritual, the mantra shundhvam daivyayakarmaṇa is recited for the purpose of purification.

original: tatra saṃdihyate kiṃ samākhyānasya balīyastvātpuroḍāśapātrāṇāṃ śundhane viniyoktavyaḥ /
analyzed: tatra saṃdihyate kim samākhyānasya balīyaḥ tvāt puroḍāśa pātrāṇām śundhane viniyoktavyaḥ
translated: There it is doubted: Should it be applied to the purification of the vessels for the purodasha cakes because the designation is stronger?

analyzed: āho sānnāyya pātrāṇām śundhane kramaḥ balīyān iti
translated: Or is the order stronger in the purification of the vessels for the sannayya?

analyzed: kim tāvat prāptam
translated: What is the prima facie view?

original: samākhyānāṃ balīya iti pauroḍāśikaśabdena hi puroḍāśasaṃbandhīnītyucyante tānyadhikṛtya pravṛttaṃ kāṇḍaṃ pauroḍāśikam /
analyzed: samākhyānām balīyaḥ iti pauroḍāśika śabdena hi puroḍāśa saṃbandhīni iti ucyante tāni adhikṛtya pravṛttam kāṇḍam pauroḍāśikam
translated: The designation is stronger, because by the word paurodashika it is said to be related to the purodasha cakes. The section that occurs with reference to them is the paurodashika.

analyzed: tatas ca
translated: And from that,

analyzed: yāvat krameṇa prakaraṇa ādi anumāna paramparayā saṃbandhaḥ pratipādanīyaḥ yāvat samākhyayā
translated: as much as the connection is to be established by the chain of inference from the context, as much as by the designation,

original: śrutyaiva sākṣādeva sa pratipādita iti arthaviprakarṣeṇa kramātsamākhyaiva balīyasīti
analyzed: śrutyā eva sākṣāt eva sa pratipāditaḥ iti artha viprakarṣeṇa kramāt samākhyā eva balīyasī iti
translated: The order is stronger than the name, because of the remoteness of the meaning.

original: puroḍāśapātraśundhane mantraḥ prayoktavyaḥ na sānnāyyapātraśundhana iti prāptam /
analyzed: puroḍāśa pātra śundhane mantraḥ prayoktavyaḥ na sānnāyya pātra śundhane iti prāptam
translated: Therefore, the mantra should be used for purifying the vessel of the purodasha cake, not for purifying the vessel of the sannāyya.

original: evaṃ prāpte 'bhidhīyatesamākhyānātkramo balavānarthaviprakarṣāditi /🔽tathāhisamākhyā na tāvatsaṃbandhasya vācikā kintu pauroḍāśaviśiṣṭaṃ kāṇḍamāha /
analyzed: evam prāpte bhidhīyate samākhyānāt kramaḥ balavān artha viprakarṣāt iti  tathā hi samākhyā na tāvat saṃbandhasya vācikā kintu pauroḍāśa viśiṣṭam kāṇḍam āha
translated: This being the prima facie view, it is said: Order is stronger than name, because of the remoteness of the meaning.🔽For thus, the name does not directly express the connection, but rather it denotes the section qualified by the purodasha.

original: tadviśiṣṭatvānyathānupapattyā tu saṃbandhaḥ kāṇḍasyānumīyate na tu sākṣānmantrabedasya /
analyzed: tad viśiṣṭa tva anyathā anupapattyā tu saṃbandhaḥ kāṇḍasya anumīyate na tu sākṣāt mantrabedasya
translated: But the connection of the section is inferred by the impossibility of its being qualified by that, not directly of the mantra.

analyzed: tad dhāreṇa ca tad madhya pātinaḥ mantra bhedasya api tad anumānam
translated: And the inference of that mantra also, which falls in between, is by means of that bearer.

original: na cāsau saṃbandho 'pi śrutyaiva śeṣaśeṣibhāvaḥ pratīyate /
analyzed: na ca asau śrutyā eva śeṣa śeṣi bhāvaḥ pratīyate
translated: And that connection is not understood by the Vedic text itself as the relation of the subsidiary and the primary.

analyzed: api tu saṃbandha mātram
translated: But rather, it is merely the connection.

analyzed: tasmāt śruti sādṛśyam asya dūra apetam iti krameṇa na asya spardhā ucitā
translated: Therefore, this [order] is far removed from similarity with the Vedic text. Thus, it is not fit to compete with [the Vedic text].

analyzed: tatra api ca sāmānyatas darśa pūrṇamāsa prakaraṇa āpādita aidamarthyasya śaunaḥśepa upākhyāna ādi vat cārāt upakāraka tayā prakṛta mātra saṃbandha anupapattiḥ
translated: And even there, the purpose of the Śunaḥśepa story, etc., which is brought in by the context of the new and full moon sacrifices, is not connected with the main subject matter as being of incidental benefit, like the Śunaḥśepa story, etc.

analyzed: mantrasya prayoga samaveta artha smāraṇena sāmavāyikā aṅga tvāt  tathā ca yaṃ
translated: Because the mantra is a subsidiary part by reminding of the meaning connected with the performance.

analyzed: kañcid prakṛta prayoga gatam artham prakāśayataḥ sya prakaraṇa aṅga tvam aviruddham iti viśeṣa apekṣāyām
translated: And thus, of any meaning that is manifested in a particular performance, its being a part of the context is not contradicted. So when there is an expectation of a particular [meaning],

original: sānnāyyakramaḥ sānnāyyaṃ prati prakaraṇādyanumānadvāreṇa viniyogaṃ kalpayitumutsahate na tu samākhyānam /
analyzed: sānnāyya kramaḥ sānnāyyam prati prakaraṇa ādi anumāna dvāreṇa viniyogam kalpayitum utsahate na tu samākhyānam
translated: the sequence of the Sannāya offering is able to imagine the application by means of the inference of the context and so on with regard to the Sannāya offering, but not the designation.

analyzed: tasya durbala tvāt
translated: Because that is weak.

original: tathāhisamākhyā saṃbandhanibandhanā sati tatsidhyarthaṃ saṃnidhimupakalpayati yāvattādvaidikena pratyakṣadṛṣṭena saṃnidhānenākāṅkṣā kalpyate
analyzed: tathā hi samākhyā saṃbandha nibandhanā sati tad sidhi artham saṃnidhim upakalpayati yāvat tādvaidikena pratyakṣa dṛṣṭena saṃnidhānena ākāṅkṣā kalpyate
translated: For thus, the designation, being based on the relation, imagines the proximity in order to establish that, as long as the expectation is imagined by the proximity seen directly in the Veda.

original: yāvacca kḷptena saṃnidhānenākāṅkṣā kalpyate tāvaditaratra kḷptayākāṅkṣayaikavākyatā yāvacca kḷptayākāṅkṣaikavākyatā tāvaditaratraikavākyatayā 🔽kḷptayopakārasāmarthyam /
analyzed: yāvat ca kḷptena saṃnidhānena ākāṅkṣā kalpyate tāvat itaratra kḷptayā ākāṅkṣayā eka vākya tā yāvat ca kḷptayā ākāṅkṣā eka vākya tā tāvat itaratra eka vākya tayā  kḷptayā upakāra sāmarthyam
translated: As long as the requirement is assumed through the established proximity, for that long, in the other, the syntactical connection is by the established requirement. As long as there is syntactical connection by the established requirement, for that long, in the other, the capability of assisting is established by the syntactical connection.

analyzed: yāvat ca atra eka vākya tayā upakāra sāmarthyam tāvat itaratra liṅgena viniyojikā śrutiḥ
translated: As long as there is capability of assisting by the syntactical connection here, for that long, in the other, the injunctive Vedic text is by the indicative power.

original: yāvadatra liṅgena viniyojikā śrutistāvaditaratra kḷptayā śrutyā viniyoga iti tāvataiva
analyzed: yāvat atra liṅgena viniyojikā śrutiḥ tāvat itaratra kḷptayā śrutyā viniyogaḥ iti tāvatā eva
translated: As long as there is an injunctive Vedic text by the indicative power here, for that long, in the other, the application is by the established Vedic text. By that much alone,

original: prakaraṇapāṭhopapatteḥ sarvaṃ samākhyānakalpitaṃ vicchinnamūlatvāllūyamānaśasyamiva nirbījaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: prakaraṇa pāṭha upapatteḥ sarvam samākhyāna kalpitam vicchinna mūla tvāt lūyamāna śasyam iva nirbījam bhavati
translated: because the recitation of the context is appropriate, everything imagined by the designation becomes severed at the root, like a harvested crop without seed.

analyzed: puroḍāśa abhidhāyaka mantra ābāhulyāt kāṇḍasya pauroḍāśika samākhyā iti mantavyam  eka dvi tri catuṣpañca vastu anta raya kāritam
translated: It should be understood that the section is called Paurṇamāsa because of the abundance of mantras denoting the cake.

analyzed: śruti artham prati vaiṣamyam liṅga ādīnām pratīyate
translated: The inequality of the indicative power etc. is understood with regard to the Vedic meaning, which is produced by the one, two, three, four, or five factors.

analyzed: iti artha viprakarṣaḥ uktaḥ
translated: Thus, the remoteness from the meaning has been stated.

original: tatrāpi ca 'bādhikaiva śrutirnityaṃ samākhyā bādhyate sadā /
analyzed: tatra api ca bādhikā eva śrutiḥ nityam samākhyā bādhyate sadā
translated: And even there, it is said: The Vedic text always overrides, the designation is always overridden.

analyzed: madhyamānām tu bādhya tvam bādhaka tvam apekṣayā
translated: But the middle ones are to be annulled, and the annulling is dependent on the context.

analyzed: iti viśeṣaḥ uktaḥ vṛddhaiḥ
translated: Thus the distinction has been stated by the elders.

original: tadvayaṃ vistarādbibhyato 'pi prathamatantrānabhijñānukampayā nighnā vistare patitāḥ sma ityuparamyate /
analyzed: tat vayam vistarāt bibhyataḥ pi prathama tantra anabhijña anukampayā nighnāḥ vistare patitāḥ smaḥ iti uparamyate
translated: Although we are afraid of elaborating, out of compassion for those unfamiliar with the first Tantra, we have fallen into elaboration. Thus we desist.

original: tasmādyathānujñāpanānujñayoḥ prajñātakramayorupahūta upahūyasvetyevaṃ mantrāvāmnātau deśasāmānyāttathaivāṅgatayā prāpnutaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt yathā anujñāpana anujñayoḥ prajñāta kramayoḥ upahūtaḥ upahūyasva iti evam mantrau āmnātau deśa sāmānyāt tathā eva aṅga tayā prāpnutaḥ
translated: Therefore, just as in the case of anuññāpana and anuññā, which are well-known in sequence, the mantras upahūta upahūyasva are recited, they are obtained as parts in the same way due to the common location.

original: upahūta iti liṅgato 'nujñāmantro nānujñāpane upahūyasveti ca liṅgato 'nujñāpano ca mantro nānujñāyām /
analyzed: upahūtaḥ iti liṅgataḥ nujñā mantraḥ na anujñāpane upahūyasva iti ca liṅgataḥ ca mantraḥ na anujñāyām
translated: Upahūta is the mantra for anuññā due to the gender, and it is not for anuññāpana. And upahūyasva is the mantra for anuññāpana due to the gender, and it is not for anuññā.

original: tadiha liṅgena kramaṃ bādhitvā viparītaṃ śeṣatvamāpādyate /
analyzed: tat iha liṅgena kramam bādhitvā viparītam śeṣa tvam āpādyate
translated: Therefore, here the sequence is overridden by the gender, and the opposite order of the remainder is imposed.

original: yāvaddhi sthānena prakaraṇamutpādyaikavākyatvaṃ kalpyate tāvalliṅgena śrutiṃ kalpayitvā sādhito viniyoga iti akalpitaliṅgaśruteḥ kramasya bādhaḥ
analyzed: yāvat hi sthānena prakaraṇam utpādya eka vākya tvam kalpyate tāvat liṅgena śrutim kalpayitvā sādhitaḥ viniyogaḥ iti a kalpita liṅga śruteḥ kramasya bādhaḥ
translated: For as long as the context is produced by the location and the oneness of statement is assumed, for that long the application is accomplished by assuming the Vedic text by the gender. Thus the sequence, which does not have an assumed gender or Vedic text, is overridden.

original: tadvadihāpi viniyoge pratyekāntaritena liṅgena caturantaritasya vidyākramasya bādha iti /
analyzed: tadvat iha api viniyoge pratyeka antaritena liṅgena catur antaritasya vidyā kramasya bādhaḥ iti
translated: In the same way, here also, the sequence of the knowledge is overridden by the gender, which is interrupted by each individual, and is four times interrupted.

original: yadyapi prathamatantra evāyamartha upapāditastathāpi virodhe tadupapādanamiha tvavirodhaḥ /
analyzed: yadi api prathama tantre eva ayam arthaḥ upapāditaḥ tathā api virodhe tad upapādanam iha tu avirodhaḥ
translated: Although this matter has been discussed in the first Adhikaraṇa, yet it is discussed here in order to show that there is no contradiction in the case of the mantra in question.

analyzed: nahi liṅgena ābhicārika karma saṃbandhaḥ vidyā saṃbandhena krama kṛtena virudhyate
translated: For the connection of the mantra with the Abhicharuka rite is not contradicted by its connection with the Vidyā, which is established in a different order of sequence.

analyzed: na ca viniyukta viniyoga lakṣaṇaḥ virodhaḥ bṛhaspatisave pi tad prasaṅgāt
translated: Nor is there a contradiction here in the form of one injunction superseding another, as that would lead to the absurdity of the Brihaspatisava rite being superseded.

original: athaiva pratītivirodho naca vastuvirodhaḥ sa vidyāyāṃ viniyoge 'pi tulyaḥ /🔽tasmādavirodhādvedhādimantrasyopāsanāṅgatvamityastyabhyadhikā śaṅkā /
analyzed: athā eva pratīti virodhaḥ na ca vastu virodhaḥ sa vidyāyām viniyoge tulyaḥ  tasmāt avirodhāt vedha ādi mantrasya upāsana aṅga tvam iti asti abhyadhikā śaṅkā
translated: If it be said that there is contradiction with regard to the cognition, but not with regard to the thing itself, that is equally the case even when the mantra is employed in the Vidyā.🔽Therefore, there is a stronger doubt that the mantra containing the word 'vedha' is an auxiliary to the upāsanā, because there is no contradiction.

analyzed: tatra ucyate na hi liṅga virodhena krama bādhaḥ abhidhīyate
translated: To that it is said: 'The contradiction of sequence is not said to be due to the contradiction of the indicative.

original: kintu liṅgaparicchinne na kramaḥ kalpanākṣamaḥ' /🔽prakaraṇapāṭhopapattyā hi śrutiliṅgatvākyaprakaraṇairaviniyuktaḥ krameṇa prakaraṇavākyaliṅgaśrutikalpanāprāṇālikayā viniyujyate /
analyzed: kintu liṅga paricchinne na kramaḥ kalpanā kṣamaḥ  prakaraṇa pāṭha upapattyā hi śruti liṅga tva ākya prakaraṇaiḥ a viniyuktaḥ krameṇa prakaraṇa vākya liṅga śruti kalpanā prāṇālikayā viniyujyate
translated: But when the indicative is ascertained, the sequence cannot be imagined.'🔽For the mantra, which is not employed by the context, the recitation, the indicative power, the syntactical connection, and the context, is employed by the sequence, by the context, the syntactical connection, and the indicative power, through the channel of imagination.

analyzed: tadā viniyuktasya prakaraṇa pāṭha ānarthakya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because if it were employed in that way, it would lead to the absurdity of the recitation of the context being meaningless.

original: upapādite tu śrutyādibhi prakaraṇapāṭhe kṣīṇatvādarthāpatteḥ kramo na
analyzed: upapādite tu prakaraṇa pāṭhe kṣīṇa tvāt arthāpatteḥ kramaḥ na
translated: But when the context is established by Śruti etc., since the presumption is weakened, the order

analyzed: svocitām pramām utpādayitum arhati pramitsā abhāvāt iti
translated: cannot produce its own cognition, because there is no desire to know.

analyzed: bṛhaspatisavasya tu ktvā śrutiḥ eva dhātu saṃbandha adhikārakāt samāna kartṛka tāyām vihitā
translated: But in the case of the Brihaspatisava, the mention of the ktvā suffix, which is prescribed for the connection of the same agent with the verbal root,

original: saṃyogapṛthaktvena viniyuktamapi viniyojayantī na śakyā śrutyantareṇa niroddhuṃ svapramāmiti vaiṣamyam /
analyzed: saṃyoga pṛthaktvena viniyuktam api viniyojayantī na śakyā śruti antareṇa niroddhum sva pramām iti vaiṣamyam
translated: even though employed separately by the connection, cannot be prevented by another Śruti from producing its own cognition, so there is a difference.

analyzed: tat idam uktam
translated: This is what is said:

analyzed: vājapeye tu bṛhaspatisavasya spaṣṭam viniyoga antaram iti
translated: But in the Vajapeya, there is a clear different application of the Brihaspatisava.

analyzed: api ca ekaḥ yam pravargyaḥ iti
translated: Moreover, this Pravargya is one.

original: tulyabalatayā bṛhaspatisavasya tulyatāśaṅkāpākaraṇadvāreṇa samuccayo na tu pṛthaguktitayā parasparāpekṣatvāditi /
analyzed: tulya bala tayā bṛhaspatisavasya tulya tā śaṅkā apākaraṇa dvāreṇa samuccayaḥ na tu pṛthak ukti tayā paraspara apekṣa tvāt iti
translated: By the doubt being removed that the Brihaspatisava is equal due to being of equal strength, there is combination by the door of removing the doubt of equality, but not by separate mention, because of mutual dependence.

analyzed: saṃnidhi pāṭham upapādayati
translated: He explains the reading in close proximity:

analyzed: araṇya ādi vacanavāt iti  start
translated: As in the case of the words beginning with 'forest'.

original: hānau tūpāyanaśabdaśeṣatvāt kuśāc chandaḥstutyupagānavat tad uktam / / / /
analyzed: hānau tu upāyana śabda śeṣa tvāt kuśāt chandaḥ stuti upagāna vat tat uktam  /
translated: In the case of relinquishment, however, because of being a remainder of the word 'upavana', like the chanting of the hymns from the Kusha bundle, that has been stated.

original: yatra hānopāyane śrūyete tatrāvivādaḥ saṃnipāte yatrāpyupāyanamātraśravaṇaṃ tatrāpi nāntarīyakatayā hānamākṣiptamityasti saṃnipātaḥ /
analyzed: yatra hāna upāyane śrūyete tatra avivādaḥ saṃnipāte yatra api upāyana mātra śravaṇam tatra api nāntarīyaka tayā hānam ākṣiptam iti asti saṃnipātaḥ
translated: Where the terms 'giving up' and 'taking up' are heard, there is no dispute about their combination. Where only 'taking up' is heard, even there 'giving up' is implied as an invariable concomitant, so there is combination.

original: yatra tu hānamātraṃ sakṛtaduṣkṛtayoḥ śrutaṃ na śrūyate upāyanaṃ /
analyzed: yatra tu hāna mātram sakṛta duṣkṛtayoḥ śrutam na śrūyate upāyanam
translated: But where only 'giving up' of good and bad deeds is heard, and 'taking up' is not heard,

analyzed: tatra kim upāyanam upādānam saṃnipatet na vā iti saṃśayaḥ
translated: there is doubt whether 'taking up' should be included or not.

analyzed: atra pūrvapakṣam gṛhṇāti
translated: Here he takes up the prima facie view

analyzed: asaṃnipāte iti
translated: that there is no combination.

analyzed: syāt etat
translated: This might be thought:

analyzed: yathā śrūyamāṇam ekatra śākhāyām upāsana aṅgam tasmin eva upāsane śākhā antare śrūyamāṇam upasaṃhriyate
translated: Just as what is heard as an accessory of meditation in one branch is included in that very meditation even when not heard in another branch,

analyzed: evam śākhā antara śrutam upāyanam upasaṃhariṣyate iti atas āha
translated: so the 'taking up' heard in another branch will be included. To this he says

analyzed: vidyā antara gocara tvāt ca iti
translated: and because it belongs to a different knowledge.

analyzed: eka tve hi upāsana karmaṇām anyatra śrutānām api anyatra samavāyaḥ ghaṭate
translated: For if the actions of meditation were one, then what is heard elsewhere could be combined elsewhere.

analyzed: na tu iha upāsanānām eka tvam
translated: But here the meditations are not one.

analyzed: sa guṇa nirguṇa tvena bhedāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that they are different because of having qualities and being without qualities.

original: nanu yathopāyanaṃ śrutaṃ hānamupasthāpayatyevaṃ hānamapi upāyanamityata āha
analyzed: nanu yathā upāyanam śrutam hānam upasthāpayati evam hānam api upāyanam iti atas āha
translated: But just as 'taking up' implies 'giving up' when heard, so 'giving up' implies 'taking up'. To this he says

analyzed: api ca ātma kartṛkam iti
translated: Moreover, it is said to be done by the self.

analyzed: sa ca śarīra adhīna tayā dṛśyamānaḥ śarīra dharmaḥ evam prāṇaḥ śvāsa praśvāsa ādi rūpaḥ śarīra dharmaḥ eva
translated: And that being seen as dependent on the body, the body is its property. Life-breath, in the form of inhalation and exhalation, is also a property of the body.

original: icchāprayatnādayaśca yadyapyāntarāḥ tathāpi śarīrātiriktasya tadāśrayānupalabdheḥ sati śarīre bhāvāt antaḥ śarīrāśrayā eva /
analyzed: icchā prayatna ādayaḥ ca yadi api āntarāḥ tathā api śarīra atiriktasya tad āśraya anupalabdheḥ sati śarīre bhāvāt antar śarīra āśrayāḥ eva
translated: And although desire, effort, etc. are internal, still, because they are found to exist when there is a body and not otherwise, they are to be attributed to the body alone, not to anything apart from the body.

analyzed: anyathā dṛṣṭa hāna adṛṣṭa kalpanā prasaṅgāt  śarīra atirikte ātmani
translated: Otherwise, there would be the fallacy of abandoning what is seen and assuming what is not seen.

analyzed: pramāṇa abhāvāt śarīre ca saṃbhavāt śarīram eva icchā ādimat ātmā iti prāptaḥ ucyate
translated: In the absence of any proof for a self apart from the body, and its being possible in the body, it is concluded that the body alone, endowed with desire, etc., is the self.

analyzed: start
translated: This is said...🔽The exclusion is because of the invariable concomitance of that, not like perception...

analyzed: vyatirekaḥ tad bhāva bhāvi tvāt na tu upalabdhi vat
translated: The absence is due to the presence of that, not like the perception.🔽.🔽

original: nāpratyakṣaṃ pramāṇamiti bruvāṇaḥ praṣṭavyo jāyate kuto bhavānanumānādīnāmaprāmāṇyamavadhāritavāniti /
analyzed: na apratyakṣam pramāṇam iti bruvāṇaḥ praṣṭavyaḥ jāyate kutas bhavān anumāna ādīnām aprāmāṇyam avadhāritavān iti
translated: One who asserts that inference, etc., are not means of valid knowledge, should be asked: From what have you ascertained that inference, etc., are not means of valid knowledge?

analyzed: pratyakṣam hi liṅga ādi rūpa mātra grāhi na aprāmāṇyam eṣām viniścetum arhati
translated: For perception, which grasps only the form of the inferential mark, etc., cannot ascertain their invalidity.

analyzed: nahi dhūma jñānam iva eṣām indriya artha sannikarṣāt aprāmāṇya jñānam udetum arhati
translated: For the knowledge of their invalidity cannot arise from the contact of sense with object, like the knowledge of smoke.

analyzed: kintu deśa kāla avasthā rūpa bhedena

analyzed: na ca etāvān pratyakṣasya vyāpāraḥ saṃbhavati
translated: And this much activity is not possible for perception.

analyzed: yathā āhuḥ nahi idam iyataḥ vyāpārān kartum samartham saṃnihita viṣaya balena utpatteḥ avicāraka tvāt iti
translated: As they say: This is not capable of performing so many operations, because it arises by the power of the object present, and is non-reflective.

analyzed: tasmāt asmin an icchatā api pramāṇa antaram abhyupeyam

analyzed: api ca pratipannam pumāṃsam apahāya apratipanna saṃdigdhāḥ prekṣāvadbhiḥ pratipādyante
translated: Moreover, the unlearned and doubtful are taught by the wise, setting aside the learned person who has attained.

analyzed: na ca eṣām itthaṃbhāvaḥ bhavat pratyakṣa gocaraḥ

analyzed: na khalu ete gaura tva ādi vat pratyakṣa gocarāḥ kintu vacana ceṣṭā ādi liṅga anumeyāḥ

translated: And there is no inference by which these can be established.

original: na puṃsāmitthaṃbhāvamavijñāya yaṃ kañcana puruṣaṃ pratipipātayiṣato 'navadheyavacanasya prekṣāvattā nāma /
analyzed: na puṃsām itthaṃbhāvam a vijñāya yam kañcana puruṣam pratipipātayiṣataḥ navadheya vacanasya prekṣāvat tā nāma
translated: And it is not reasonable for one who does not know the nature of things in this way, and who wishes to lead any person [to the truth], to speak words that are not to be heeded.

analyzed: pariharanti ca āśyāna tṛṇa kaṇṭaka ākīrṇām

analyzed: nāstikaḥ tu paśoḥ api paśuḥ iṣṭa niṣṭa sādhanam avidvān

analyzed: na khalu asmin umāna gocara pravṛtti nivṛtti gocare pratyakṣam prabhavati

original: tadeva mā nāma bhūnnāstikasya janmāntaramasminneva janmanyupasthito 'sya mūkatvapravṛttinivṛttiviraharūpo mahānnarakaḥ /
analyzed: tat eva mā nāma bhūt nāstikasya janmāntaram asmin eva janmani upasthitaḥ sya mūka tva pravṛtti nivṛtti viraha rūpaḥ mahān narakaḥ
translated: Let that alone be so. But in this very life, this great hell in the form of dumbness, activity and cessation, which is present for the atheist, has come about.

analyzed: parākrāntam ca atra sūribhiḥ

original: bhūyaḥsāmānyayogena copamānamupapāditaṃ pramāṇalakṣaṇe /🔽tadatrāstu tāvatpramāṇāntaraṃ pratyakṣamevāhaṃpratyayaḥ śarīrātiriktamālambata ityanvayatirekābhyāmavadhāryate /
analyzed: bhūyas sāmānya yogena ca upamānam upapāditam pramāṇa lakṣaṇe  tat atra astu tāvat pramāṇa antaram pratyakṣam eva ahaṃpratyayaḥ śarīra atiriktam ālambate iti anvaya tirekābhyām avadhāryate
translated: And the analogy has been established by the connection with the general property in the definition of means of valid knowledge.🔽Here, let there be a means of valid knowledge other than this. It is ascertained by positive and negative concomitance that the cognition of 'I' has as its object something different from the body.

analyzed: yogavyāghra vat svapna daśāyām ca śarīra antara parigraha abhimāne pi ahaṅkāra āspadasya pratyabhijñāyamāna tvam iti uktam
translated: And it has been said that in the state of dream, even when there is the notion of taking up another body, the substratum of the sense of 'I' is recognized.

original: sūtrayojanā tu na tvavyatiriktaḥ kintu vyatirikta ātmā dehāt /

analyzed: kutas tad bhāva abhāvi tvāt

analyzed: caitanya ādiḥ yadi śarīra guṇaḥ tatas nena viśeṣa guṇena bhavitavyam

analyzed: na tu saṃkhyā parimāṇa saṃyoga ādi vat sāmānya guṇena

original: tathāca ye bhūtaviśeṣaguṇāste yāvadbhūtabhāvino dṛṣṭā yathā rūpādayaḥ /

analyzed: etena icchā ādīnām śarīra viśeṣa guṇa tvam pratyuktam

original: prāṇaceṣṭādayo yadyapi dehadharmā eva tathāpi na dehamātraprabhavāḥ /

analyzed: mṛta avasthāyām api prasaṅgāt

analyzed: vaidharmya antaram āha

analyzed: na ca bahūnām cetanānām anyonya abhiprāya anuvidhāna saṃbhavaḥ iti eka pāśa nibaddhāḥ iva bahavaḥ vihaṅgamāḥ viruddha ādi kriyā abhimukhāḥ samarthāḥ api na hasta mātram api  deśam atipatitum utsahante
translated: And it is not possible for many consciousnesses to conform to each other's intentions. Therefore, like many birds bound by a single rope, even though capable, they are not able to fly even a mere distance, facing contradictory actions.

original: na khalvavidheyaṃ saṃstūyate tadarthatvātsaṃstavasyetyāhayadāpīti /🔽atrāvāntaravicāramārabhatesā ca kiṃ caturṣviti /
analyzed: na khalu avidheyam saṃstūyate tad artha tvāt saṃstavasya iti āha yadā api iti  atra avāntaravicāram ārabhate sā ca kim caturṣu iti
translated: For what is not to be enjoined is not praised, because the eulogy is for that purpose. He says this in 'Even when there is mere mention.'

analyzed: vicāra prayojanam āha yadi ca iti
translated: Here he begins an intermediate discussion: And is that (state of being established in Brahman) in the four (stages of life) or in the other (stages of life)?🔽He states the purpose of the discussion: And if (it is in the other stages of life), then (the state of being established in Brahman) is not enjoined.

analyzed: nanu anāśramī eva brahma saṃsthaḥ bhaviṣyati iti atas āha anāśrayam itvā iti
translated: But surely one will be established in Brahman without (belonging to) any stage of life? To this he says: If (it is in the other stages of life), then (the state of being established in Brahman) is not enjoined.

analyzed: tatra pūrvapakṣam āha tatra tapaḥ śabdena iti
translated: There he states the prima facie view: There (in the passage), by the word 'austerity' (the state of being established in Brahman) is enjoined for the other stages of life.

analyzed: ayam abhisaṃdhiḥ
translated: This is the intention:

original: yadi tāvadbrahmasaṃstha iti padaṃ pratyastamitāvayavārthaṃ parivrājake 'śvakarṇādipadavadrūḍhaṃ tadāśramaprāptimātreṇaivāmṛtībhāva iti na tadbhāvāyā
analyzed: yadi tāvat brahma saṃsthaḥ iti padam pratyastamita avayava artham parivrājake śvakarṇa ādi pada vat rūḍham tad āśrama prāpti mātreṇa eva amṛtībhāvaḥ iti na tad bhāvāyāḥ
translated: If the term 'brahmasaṃstha' is a conventional term for the wandering ascetic, like the term 'aśvakarṇa' etc., with its component meanings completely merged, then immortality is attained merely by attaining that stage, and there is no need for any other state to attain it.

analyzed: brahma jñānam apekṣeta
translated: If the word ‘Brahmasaṃstha’ is a conventional one, like the word ‘Aśvakarṇa’ (a kind of grass), the component parts of which have become merged in the conventional name, then Immortality would follow from the mere attaining of the stage of Renunciation; and in that case, for attaining that stage, it would not be necessary to have the knowledge of Brahman.

analyzed: tathā ca na anyaḥ panthāḥ vidyate yanāya iti virodhaḥ
translated: And this would be contrary to the declaration that ‘there is no other path for the going of this (Soul)’;

analyzed: na ca saṃbhati avayava arthe samudāya śakti kalpanā  tasmāt brahmaṇi saṃsthāsye iti
translated: and it is not right to assume the potency of a whole word in the case of a word whose component parts are all well known.

analyzed: brahma saṃsthaḥ
translated: From all this it follows that the right explanation is that the man is ‘Brahmasaṃstha’, ‘resting in Brahman’, who is ‘sthitaḥ’, ‘established’, in ‘brahma’, Brahman.

original: evañca caturṣvāśrameṣu yasyaiva brahmaṇi niṣṭhatvamāśramiṇaḥ sa brahmasaṃstho 'mṛtatvametīti yuktam /
analyzed: evam ca caturṣu āśrameṣu yasya eva brahmaṇi niṣṭha tvam āśramiṇaḥ sa brahma saṃsthaḥ mṛta tvam eti iti yuktam
translated: And in this way, it is only right that of the four life-stages, it is only he who is ‘established in Brahman’ who attains Immortality.

original: tatra tāvadbrahmacārigṛhasthau svaśabdābhihitau tapaḥpadena ca tapaḥpradhānatayā bhikṣuvānaprasthāvupasthāpitau /
analyzed: tatra tāvat brahmacāri gṛhasthau sva śabda abhihitau tapaḥ padena ca tapaḥ pradhāna tayā bhikṣu vānaprasthau upasthāpitau
translated: Of these, the Religious Student and the Householder are mentioned by their own names; and the Hermit and the Renunciate are mentioned by the term ‘tapah’, ‘austerity’, which indicates the performance of austerities which forms the principal part of their duties.

analyzed: bhikṣuḥ api hi samādhika śauca aṣṭa grāsī bhojana niyamāt bhavati vānaprastha vat tapaḥ pradhānaḥ
translated: The Renunciate also, by the performance of his duties, becomes one whose principal duty is the performance of austerities, in the shape of the Restraints and Observances, such as the keeping of the sacred fires, the eating of food got by begging and so forth.

analyzed: na ca gṛhastha ādeḥ karmiṇaḥ brahma niṣṭha tva asaṃbhavaḥ
translated: Nor is it impossible for the Householder and others, who are engaged in the performance of their duties, to be ‘established in Brahman’.

original: yadi tāvatkarmayogaḥ karmitā sā bhikṣorapi kāyavāṅmanobhirasti /
analyzed: yadi tāvat karma yogaḥ karmi tā sā bhikṣoḥ api kāya vāc manobhiḥ asti
translated: If it is the yoga of action, then that is the state of being an agent, which exists even for a monk through body, speech, and mind.

original: atha ye na brahmārpaṇena karma kurvanti kintu kāmārthitayā te karmiṇaḥ /🔽tathā sati gṛhasthādayo 'pi brahmārpaṇena karma kurvāṇā na karmiṇaḥ /
analyzed: atha ye na brahmārpaṇena karma kurvanti kintu kāma arthi tayā te karmiṇaḥ  tathā sati gṛhastha ādayaḥ pi brahma arpaṇena karma kurvāṇāḥ na karmiṇaḥ
translated: If, on the other hand, those who do not perform actions by offering them to Brahman, but rather out of desire for results, are the agents,🔽then even householders and others, who perform actions by offering them to Brahman, are not agents.

original: tasmādbrahmaṇi tātparyaṃ brahmaniṣṭhatā na tu karmatyāgaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt brahmaṇi tātparyam brahma niṣṭha tā na tu karma tyāgaḥ
translated: Therefore, being intent on Brahman is being devoted to Brahman, not renouncing actions.

analyzed: pramāṇa virodhāt
translated: Because that contradicts the means of valid knowledge.

original: tapasā ca dvayorāśramayorekīkaraṇena traya iti tritvamupapadyate /
analyzed: tapasā ca dvayoḥ āśramayoḥ ekīkaraṇena trayaḥ iti tri tvam upapadyate
translated: And by austerity, the two stages of life are combined, so the number three is justified.

original: evañca trayo 'pyāśramā abrahmasaṃsthāḥ santaḥ puṇyalokabhājo bhavanti yaḥ punareteṣu brahmasaṃsthaḥ so 'mṛtatvabhāgiti /
analyzed: evam ca trayaḥ pi āśramāḥ a brahma saṃsthāḥ santaḥ puṇya loka bhājaḥ bhavanti yaḥ punar eteṣu brahma saṃsthaḥ saḥ mṛta tva bhāj iti
translated: And thus, all three stages of life, being not devoted to Brahman, attain the world of the virtuous, but he who is devoted to Brahman among them attains immortality.

analyzed: na ca yeṣām puṇya loka bhāj tvam teṣām eva amṛta tvam iti virodhaḥ
translated: And it is not contradictory that those who attain the world of the virtuous attain immortality.

original: yathā devadattayajñadattau mandaprajñāvabhūtāṃ saṃprati tayoryajñādattastu śāstrābhyāsātpaṭuprajño vartate iti tathehāpi ya evābrahmasaṃsthāḥ
analyzed: yathā devadatta yajñadattau manda prajñau abhūtām saṃprati tayoḥ yajñādattaḥ tu śāstra abhyāsāt paṭu prajñaḥ vartate iti tathā iha api ye eva a brahma saṃsthāḥ
translated: Just as Devadatta and Yajnadatta were dull-witted in the past, but now Yajnadatta is sharp-witted due to studying the scriptures, so it is here also. Those who are not devoted to Brahman,

translated: They alone who are established in Brahman attain the world of the virtuous and immortality. Thus there is no contradiction due to the difference in states.

original: tathāca brahmasaṃstha iti yaugikaṃ padaṃ prakṛtaviṣayaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: tathā ca brahma saṃsthaḥ iti yaugikam padam prakṛta viṣayam bhaviṣyati
translated: And thus the etymologically correct word 'brahmasaṃstha' will refer to the subject matter at hand.

original: yathā āgneyyāgnīdhramupatiṣṭhata ityatra viniyuktāpi prakṛtaivāgneyī gṛhyate /
